title: Behavior of switches --ropsten and --networkid 3 different
body:
#### System information

```
Version: 1.10.16-stable
Git Commit: 20356e57b119b4e70ce47665a71964434e15200d
Architecture: amd64
Go Version: go1.17.5
Operating System: linux
```

#### Expected behaviour

Starting server with networkid=3 should behave the same way as starting it with --ropsten

#### Actual behaviour

Starting server with networkid=3 results in connecting to no peers, even after a sustained period.

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
1. Start the server using the `--ropsten` switch.
  ```runuser -l geth_user -c "nohup geth --datadir /home/geth_user/go_ethereum --ropsten --syncmode snap --vmodule admin=4,debug=3,eth=3,ethash=3,miner=3,net=3,personal=3,rpc=5,txpool=3,web3=5 --rpc.txfeecap 0 --rpc.gascap 0 --http --http.addr 0.0.0.0 --http.api "eth,net,web3,personal,db" --http.corsdomain '*' --http.vhosts '*' --ws --ws.api "eth,net,web3,personal,db" --ws.addr 0.0.0.0 --ws.origins '*' --ws.rpcprefix '/' 2>&1 | logger &" ```

3. Stop the server.
4. Execute `rm -rf` on the chaindata directory
5. Restart the server, but this time replacing ```--ropsten``` with ```--networkid 3```
```
runuser -l geth_user -c "nohup geth --datadir /home/geth_user/go_ethereum --networkid 3 --syncmode snap --vmodule admin=4,debug=3,eth=3,ethash=3,miner=3,net=3,personal=3,rpc=5,txpool=3,web3=5 --rpc.txfeecap 0 --rpc.gascap 0 --http --http.addr 0.0.0.0 --http.api "eth,net,web3,personal,db" --http.corsdomain '*' --http.vhosts '*' --ws --ws.api "eth,net,web3,personal,db" --ws.addr 0.0.0.0 --ws.origins '*' --ws.rpcprefix '/' 2>&1 | logger &"
```

This issue is possibly related to #24202 

Also tried ```networkid 3``` and ```networkid=3```

Connections between blockchain nodes will occur only if both peers use the same genesis block and network ID.
`--ropsten` flag is a shortcut to both set genesis block and network ID, it's recommended to use.
Is the intent to use the --networkid switch only for private blockchains?

> Is the intent to use the --networkid switch only for private blockchains?

Use the `networkid` for specifying the network and use `geth init` for initializing your private network genesis block.
Otherwise, just use the testnet identifier instead.
